paragraphs: a well defined collection of objects
Eg : Set of flowers,set of natural numbers, set of English alphabet,
If 'A' is any set, every object in A is called an element of the Set.
Ex : If $@"A = (a, b, c, d ),\;a"@$ belongs to A, but e does not belong to A, then a = A but e = A.

A set which has only one element is called a "Singleton Set"
Ex : A Set of even pritne nutnber (i.e.) ( 2 )
A set which has a finite number of elements is called a "finite set."
Ex : x = (a, e, i, o, u)
A set containing no elements is called a null set (or) empty set (or) void set and it is denoted by 0 (or) ().
Ex : Set of whole numbers greater than 8 but less than 5.
A set which has an infinite number of elements is called an infinite set.
Two sets A and B are called equal sets if both contain the same elements.
Two sets A and B are called equivalent sets if they contain the same number of elements.
All equal sets are equivalent but all equivalent sets need not be equal.
A Set 'A' is called a subset of set 'B' if every element of A is in B. It is denoted by A C B.
If 'A' is a subset of 'B' and A B then A is called a proper subset of B. It is denoted by A c B.
The number of distinct elements in the Set 'A' is called Cardinal number of the set A. It is denoted by n (A).
The set of all Subsets of 'A' is called the power set and it is denoted by P(A).
Eg. : If A = (a, b, c) then P(A) = ,
The number of power sets of a set is 2n where n is the number of elements of a set.
(i) Every set is a subset of itself.
(ii) Empty set is a subset of every set.
The union of two sets 'A' and 'B' is A U B. It denotes all elements of the two sets.
AUB = (x : x e A (or) x e B (or) x e both A and B)
Eg. : Let A = (a, p, l, e), B = (o, r, a, n, g, e] then AUB= (a, p, 1, e, 0, r, n, g)
Note : The common elements 'a' and 'e' have to be taken only once while writing A U B.
The intersection oftwo sets 'A' and 'B' is A B. It denotes only the elements which are common to both sets.

Two sets A and B are said to be disjoint if there is no common element (i.e.) A B = 7, 9) andB (2, 4, 6, 8, 10) . A and B are disjoint sets.
Laws : Let A, B and C be any three sets.

It is the set of all elements which can be considered relevant for the mathematical discussion on hand.
Let 'A' be a subset of a Universal Set 'U'. The complement of A is the set of all elements of "U" that are not in A.
We denote it by A' = (x : x e U and x e A)
